newsitem.title: QATAR: Qatar's telecommunications firm lifts 1996 profit.
newsitem.headline: Qatar's telecommunications firm lifts 1996 profit.

text.p: Qatar's state-owned telecommunications agency on Tuesday announced a "record" profit in 1996, thanks to more mobile telephone users.

Izzat al-Rashid, general manager of the Qatar Public Telecommunications Corp (Q-Tel), told reporters that profit rose 16 percent to 402 million riyals ($110 million) last year. He said 100 million riyals would be spent on improving customer services.

Rashid said Q-Tel had a good year in 1996 because the number of mobile telephone users in the tiny Gulf Arab state jumped to 25,000 in 1996 from 15,000 in 1995 while radio-pager users rose to 58,000 from 46,000 during the same period.

He said 60 percent of net revenue came from international telephone calls made from Qatar, which has 26 telephone lines for every 100 people. Qatar has a population of 560,000 people, some 440,000 of whom are expatriates.
Rashid said the corporation planned to reduce telephone call rates every two years to encourage more calls and to speed up the installation of new telephones.
Work was also underway to expand the mobile telephone network to increase capacity to 50,000 lines in 1997 and 70,000 lines next year.

Rashid said Q-Tel was considering increasing its 10 percent stake in a United Arab Emirates-based shareholding company formed earlier this year to operate and own a major new satellite project for mobile communications.
The satellite project, called al-Thurayya, is due to be operational by the turn of the century at a total cost of $800 million.
It will provide services to UAE users of mobile telephones compatible with the Global System for Mobile Communications (GSM).

Etisalat, the UAE's telecommunications heavyweight, holds a 26 percent stake in al-Thurayya and the Arab Satellite Communications Organisation (Arabsat) owns 10 percent. Other shareholders include Bahrain Telecommunications Co (10 percent).
